questions.question_text: Data from a revenue collection system is uploaded into an enterprise data warehouse to be used for reporting purposes. An IS audit identifies that some revenue transactions were uploaded into the warehouse twice. Which of the following is the GREATEST risk in this situation?

choices.A: Data in the warehouse may not be secure.
choices.D: Significant time may be required to identify double-counted transactions
choices.C: Data in the revenue collection system may not match data in the warehouse.
choices.B: Reports generated from the data warehouse may lead to incorrect, decisions.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
The greatest risk in this situation is that reports generated from the data warehouse may lead to incorrect decisions. Duplicate entries can result in inaccurate financial reporting and analysis, potentially impacting decision-making processes based on the flawed information. Decision-makers relying on these reports may make incorrect judgments, affecting the organization's overall performance and strategy.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is an IS auditor's BEST recommendation to protect an organization from attacks when its file server needs to be accessible to external users?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
Setting up a DMZ allows for the isolation of external-facing services from the internal network, providing an additional layer of security. This configuration helps protect the internal systems while allowing external users to access the necessary resources on the file server.

Selected Answer: B
The best recommendation to protect an organization from attacks when its file server needs to be accessible to external users is to enforce a secure tunnel connection. This involves using technologies such as VPN or other secure communication protocols to establish an encrypted connection between external users and the file server. This helps protect data during transmission and reduces the risk of unauthorized access or interception.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is the MOST likely reason that local area network (LAN) servers can contribute to the rapid distribution of viruses?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
The most likely reason that LAN servers can contribute to the rapid distribution of viruses is that the server's file-sharing function facilitates the distribution of files. File-sharing features on servers, especially when not properly configured or secured, can enable the rapid spread of viruses and malware across multiple workstations connected to the LAN.
